Award.AwardTitle: Support for U. S. Participants in the Max Planck Program on Geophysical Particle-Fluid Flows (Dresden, Germany, March 14-April 15, 2016)

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:
PI: Jenkins, James T.
Proposal Number: 1619768

The proposal seeks funds to partially support the attendance (which includes the registration and travel) of about 25 US scientists to the five-week long program devoted to two-phase modeling of geophysical flows that involve particles and fluids that will take place at the Max Planck Institute for the Physics of Complex Systems in Dresden, Germany, between March 14th and April 15th, 2016.

This symposium is motivated by the need to understand natural fluid-particle flow phenomena, such as (a) the influence of the unsteady mean and fluctuating velocities on particles in a turbulent flow over a range of particle concentration and ratios of particle-fluid mass density; (b) the nature of the inter-actions between particles and between the particles and fluid at the surface of a particle bed; and (c) the mechanisms by which large-scale features develop on the bed in systems driven by water or wind. Geophysical flows occur over a range of length scales, time scales, and concentrations that pose problems for present computational schemes based on the Navier-Stokes equations. At the present time, two-phase continuum formulations are the best hope for describing such flows, but they require correct physical models for terms that describe the interactions between the fluid and the particles. The development of such models will be the focus of this workshop.

Understanding the natural flows upon which the workshop is focused would benefit modeling and prediction of phenomena quite important for human life and for the economy, such as sand storms, torrents of rock and snow-melt down mountainsides, avalanches of powder and granular snow, transport of sediment by waves at coastlines, in rivers and streams, and down continental shelves. Even plumes and surges of volcanic gas and ash that can cause disruption in air transportation and agriculture fall into this category.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Geophysical fluid-particle flows include wind-blown sand, particle-laden streams discharging into lakes, transport of sediment in rivers and along coastlines, torrents of rock and snow-melt down mountainsides, powder and granular snow avalanches, and flows of particles and hot gasses or lavas from volcanoes.  Such flows cover a wide range of particle concentration and size, particle-to-fluid density ratios, and measures of flow strength.

A research program entitled Two-Phase Continuum Models for Geophysical Particle-Fluid Flows was held at the Max Planck Institute for the Physics of Complex Systems in Dresden, Germany, between March 14 and April 15, 2016.  The purpose of the program was to determine common organizing principles in these diverse geophysical flows across the range of parameters in which fluid turbulence makes an important contribution to the particle motions.  Attention was focused on the turbulent fluid flow, modulated by dilute concentrations of particles in the upper regions of the flow, particle-particle and particle-fluid interactions in denser concentrations near the bed, and erosion from and deposition to mobile beds of particles that lead to the development of bed forms. The program started with a one-week workshop and was followed by a four-week seminar.

During the program, progress was made on the understanding of flows of highly concentrated sediment under surface waves, torrents of rock debris and snow melt down mountainsides, sand transport with changes in changing winds and over varying beds, and the interaction and growth of raindrops in turbulent clouds,

The workshop and the seminar involved 41 and 28 participants, respectively; eight of the former and five of the latter were from universities in the United States: California Santa Barbara, Cornell, Delaware, Minnesota, Stanford, Texas A&M, and Washington.  The U. S. National Science Foundation supported the travel expenses of ten of these participants; this greatly facilitated their ability to participate in the workshop and/or the seminar.
